text: so this is what the center of Bangkok
looks like today
every single person dressed in black
waiting for their last chance to say
goodbye to their late King and the
numbers of people here in the center of
Bangkok today are truly extraordinary it
must be in the hundreds of thousands
that over there that golden pagoda like
building that's where the ceremony will
take place and if you look on the other
side of the street here these are the
people lining up hoping to get closer
hoping to get a glimpse of the ceremony
and this line stretches back down this
street for more than a kilometer
over the last year since the Kings death
it's estimated that 12 million Thais
have come here to Bangkok to pay their
respect these people probably have
little chance of seeing the actual
ceremony but it doesn't matter they just
want to be here we've been here since
the very early morning just a glimpse of
that crematorium and we're happy I love
him so much even when I watch his meals
on TV now I still cry it's not just I
want to be here I must be here we are
his royal subject we are his children
the funeral ceremony will begin at the
Royal Palace which you can't actually
see from here and then there will be a
five-hour procession where the funeral
urn will be carried atop a huge wooden
chariot and towed slowly through the
streets until it ends up here at the
golden pagoda building behind me and
that is where the actual cremation will
take place at 10 o'clock on Thursday
night
you
